name: Kirsten Dunst
religion: Dunst appears to be a Lutheran, but is probably non-religious.
author: Tom Kershaw

content.text: In Los Angeles, Dunst attended and graduated from a Catholic school
but as far as I can tell, she's not Catholic.
Most sites of repute have her listed as a Lutheran,
which makes sense given her German heritage (Dunst holds dual citizenship in Germany and the U.S.).

content.sourceTitle: Kirsten Dunst Zen; Dalai Lama in India
content.text: But there have been rumors that Dunst adheres to Buddhism, apparently because she does yoga and dated famous Buddhist Orlando Bloom.

Perhaps much of the confusion and rumor stems from the likelihood that Dunst just isn't that religious. She doesn't appear to have spoken about her faith or lack thereof to the press as of yet. The only weak, tenuous piece of evidence I could find was a quote about how Dunst considered getting angel wings tattooed on her back so as to have a guardian with her at all times.
We're going with Lutheran until further notice.
Dunst is a Democrat. In 2004, she came out strong for John Kerry–or should I say strong  Bush, saying:

content.sourceTitle: Celebs Go To The Post Office To Deliver Pro-Vote Message
content.text: Our country in general is kind of a mess right now, and our environment, and I just hope that [Bush] is out of office.

In 2008, she went full-on for Obama and directed a political documentary explaining why America votes on Tuesdays. The film was non-partisan, but while promoting it, Dunst used the spotlight to talk Obama. She said:

content.sourceTitle: Kirsten Dunst back in action after stint in rehab
content.text: I adore him and I'll do whatever is necessary to help him become the next president. I think he can do a lot for people of my generation . . . I love that he just lays it all on the table. . . . he's just like everything you want a president to be, I think.
On social issues, Dunst leans fairly far to the left. She's a supporter of the pro-life organization March for Women's Lives Celebrity Coalition
and drives a hybrid so she won't feel like a hypocrite at all of the environmental events she hosts.
She did rail on vegetarians once, however, saying:
I think vegetarians – for a lot of them – it's about a lack of commitment to life and relationships. There are some who just like the fact that they're controlling something in their life.
That certainly won't help her popularity among the religiously liberal.
